sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1:
A possible numerical problem related to the Schwarz reflection principle and its applications in complex analysis could be:

Consider the function $f(z)=\sin(z)$ defined on the open upper half plane $\mathbb{H}=\{z\in\mathbb{C}\mid \operatorname{Im}z>0\}$, and its reflection $g(z)=\overline{f(\bar{z})}$ across the real axis, which defines a function on the open lower half plane. Using the Schwarz reflection principle, find an expression for the analytic continuation of $f(z)$ to the closed upper half plane $\overline{\mathbb{H}}=\{z\in\mathbb{C}\mid \operatorname{Im}z\geq 0\}$, and compute the values of this continuation on the real axis from $-\pi$ to $\pi$.
message_2:
Using the Schwarz reflection principle, we can find an expression for the analytic continuation of $f(z)$ to the closed upper half plane $\overline{\mathbb{H}}$. The principle states that if $f(z)$ is analytic on the open upper half plane $\mathbb{H}$ and continuous on the real axis, then the function $h(z) = \begin{cases} f(z) & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq 0 \\ \overline{f(\bar{z})} & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) < 0 \end{cases}$ is analytic on the whole complex plane.

In our case, $f(z) = \sin(z)$, so we have:

$h(z) = \begin{cases} \sin(z) & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq 0 \\ \overline{\sin(\bar{z})} & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) < 0 \end{cases}$

Now, we want to compute the values of this continuation on the real axis from $-\pi$ to $\pi$. Since the real axis is in the closed upper half plane, we can use the expression for $f(z)$:

$h(z) = \sin(z)$ for $z \in [-\pi, \pi]$

Now, we can compute the values of $h(z)$ for the given interval:

$h(-\pi) = \sin(-\pi) = 0$

$h(-\frac{\pi}{2}) = \sin(-\frac{\pi}{2}) = -1$

$h(0) = \sin(0) = 0$

$h(\frac{\pi}{2}) = \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 1$

$h(\pi) = \sin(\pi) = 0$

So, the values of the analytic continuation of $f(z)$ on the real axis from $-\pi$ to $\pi$ are:

$h(-\pi) = 0$

$h(-\frac{\pi}{2}) = -1$

$h(0) = 0$

$h(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 1$

$h(\pi) = 0$
